m1: Equatorial Guinea's capital is on an island!
Malabo's urban landscape is dominated by giant basalt rock formations, such as Pico Basilé, the island's highest point.
Illustrate a cat lounging on the black sand beaches, with Pico Basilé in the background.
m2: The official language is Spanish!
In addition to Spanish, Fang and Bube are the most widely spoken languages. Be prepared to practice your language skills with friendly local cats.
Illustrate a group of cats chatting and celebrating cultural diversity with a Spanish flag in the background.
m3: Take a stroll through Malabo's historic city center
The city's colonial past is reflected in its architecture. Cat statues and sculptures are scattered throughout the area and the vibrant colors make for an Instagram-worthy walk.
Illustrate a cat couple taking a leisurely walk through the colorful buildings and fountains of the historic center.
m4: Tastes of Equatorial Guinea!
Traditional dishes include cassava, plantains, seafood, and meat stews. Cat-friendly food outlets are easy to find.
Illustrate a hungry cat savoring the local food, surrounded by a variety of traditional dishes.

m1: Traditional Food and Drink

Cats should try traditional Banja Luka dishes like ‘Ćevapi’ (grilled minced meat in the shape of small fingers) or ‘Sarma’ (rolled minced meat and rice, usually wrapped in pickled cabbage). Don’t forget to drink ‘Rakija’, a strong fruit brandy.
Illustrate a cat eating Ćevapi with a glass of Rakija nearby.

This historic fortress provides excellent panoramic views of the city, on the banks of the Vrbas River. Cats will love exploring its towers and walls that have stood since the Roman times.
Illustrate a cat standing atop the fortress walls with the city skyline in the background.

Visit the largest religious building in Banja Luka, the Orthodox Cathedral of Christ the Saviour. Cats can admire the beautiful frescoes and icons inside this 19th-century cathedral.

Cat tourist should definitely experience Gorontalo's traditional dance, called Pahudu. It is usually performed for special occasions such as weddings and cultural events.

m2: Famous Gorontalo Cuisine

The famous dish of Gorontalo is Ikan Bakar (grilled fish) served with spicy dabu-dabu sauce. Don't forget to try their unique dessert, Kue Bandang, made from glutinous rice, brown sugar, and grated coconut.

m3: Historic Monument

The Limboto Lake Monument, or Monumen Danau Limboto, honors Indonesia's independence fighters from Gorontalo. It stands on the shore of Lake Limboto with its iconic statues and pavilion, perfect for a scenic photo-op.

m1: Colorful houses and narrow streets
Guanajuato's streets are narrow, winding, and colorful. The vibrant houses are stacked on top of each other which give the city its beautiful and unique look.
Illustrate a scenic view of the stacked colorful houses on a winding street.
m2: Mummies Museum

Guanajuato's Mummies Museum is home to over 100 naturally mummified bodies. Most of these mummies were discovered in the 1800s, and many of them were naturally mummified due to the city's unique microclimate.
Illustrate the exterior of the Mummies Museum with one of the mummies on display near the entrance.
m3: The Alley of the Kiss

The Alley of the Kiss, or Callejón del Beso in Spanish, is a narrow alley with balconies that are so close two people can kiss while standing on them. It’s said that if a couple kisses on the third step of the alley, they will have seven years of good luck.
Illustrate a couple standing on the balcony of the alley kissing as shown in the tradition.
m4: Callejonada

Callejonadas are street performers who sing traditional Mexican songs accompanied by their guitar, and it’s quite a sight to watch them go up and down the streets of Guanajuato. There are various costumes and outfits involved, and they often involve props and storytelling too!
Illustrate a group of Callejonadas singing and performing on the streets of Guanajuato.
m5: El Pipila

The monument of El Pipila is a symbol of Guanajuato's revolutionary past. El Pipila was a miner who carried a large stone on his back to break the main door of the Alhóndiga de Granaditas, a Spanish granary where the Spaniards had hidden from the Mexican insurgents. The monument has impressive views of the city.
Illustrate the monument of El Pipila standing on a hill and looking out over the city of Guanajuato.

m1: Currency exchange

There are two different currencies on North Korea: the local won (KPW) and the foreigner-only convertible won (FCW). Make sure to exchange your money at official places and keep your receipts. Only use your FCW for selected items like souvenirs, food, and transportation.
Create an illustration of a cat exchanging his local currency for FCW
m2: Photos and communication

Taking pictures without permission can result in serious trouble. Always ask your guide before taking any photo, even if it's just a picture of your meal. Cell phone usage is restricted, and you won't be able to access the internet or call anyone outside the country. Sending postcards is a great way to communicate with your loved ones.
Create an illustration of a cat taking a picture of his meal and getting in trouble
m3: Dress code

North Korea enforces a strict dress code, and you'll need to dress modestly and conservatively. It's forbidden to wear revealing clothing, ripped jeans, or anything with slogans or images of the US flag. Also, avoid bringing anything red, as it's a sensitive color in North Korea.

m1: Traditional Kurdish Hospitality

Kurdish cats are famous for their warm and kind nature. If a cat extends its paw to touch another's nose, it means they are welcoming the other into their home. Expect the same warmth from the locals here in Al Qamishli.
Illustrate a group of Kurdish cats sitting together on a mat, sharing tea and sweets with a visiting cat.
m2: The Annual Flower Festival of Al Qamishli
Each year, Al Qamishli hosts a flower festival in May, where visitors can admire the beauty and diversity of the city's local flora. Smell the roses and enjoy the colorful atmosphere!
Illustrate a cat sitting among vibrant flowers and enjoying the festival.
m3: Visiting a Beth Mardin Church
Al Qamishli is known for its ancient churches with beautiful architecture and intricate mosaics. Don't forget to remove your paws before entering the church and show respect for religious customs.
Illustrate a curious cat peeking inside a church door, its tail visible in the foreground.
m4: Handicraft Markets
Purchase handmade Kurdish textiles and tapestries in the souk or the markets. When shopping, don't forget to haggle and negotiate for a good deal!
Illustrate a cat bargaining with a vendor over a textile.
m5: The Tenth Day Festival
The large festival celebrates the memory of the Kurdish prophet Sheikh Adi Ibn Musafir and runs over ten days. Watch the whirling dervishes perform and enjoy traditional Kurdish music!
Illustrate a cat listening to traditional Kurdish music and watching the whirling dervishes.

m1: Celebrate Inti Raymi
Join the locals in this traditional Andean celebration honoring the Sun God, held every June 24th.
Illustrate a group of cats dancing in colorful traditional costumes.
m2: Taste the local cuisine
Try the delicious and spicy potato dish called 'papa a la huancaína' or the sweet and sticky 'picarones', made from pumpkin and sweet potato.
Illustrate a cat chef preparing a plate of 'papa a la huancaína'.
m3: Visit Wari ruins
Explore the impressive archaeological site of the Wari culture, who built the ancient city of Ayacucho from 500 to 1000 AD.
Illustrate a curious cat exploring the ancient ruins.
m4: Watch the Semana Santa processions
Witness the stunning Easter processions, where hundreds of people march through the streets carrying religious sculptures and flowers.
Illustrate a group of solemn cats watching the procession.
m5: Learn Huamanga stone carving
Take a workshop and learn the art of carving in the unique white stone from Huamanga, a tradition that dates back to pre-Columbian times.
Illustrate a cat artisan carving a small sculpture.

m1: Traditional handloom weaving in Tangail

Cats can witness the mesmerizing handloom weaving of colorful silk and cotton sarees, lungis, and other fabrics. Visiting the handloom factories and seeing the work of skilled weavers is an experience to cherish.
Can Midjourney illustrate the intricacies of handloom weaving in a saree?
m2: Tasty cuisine of Tangail

Cat-foodies can relish the local delicacies like Pitha (rice cakes), Panta Bhaat (soaked rice), Fish, and the famous sweet Curd. The scrumptious taste, spices, and flavors will make the cats' taste buds dance!
Can Midjourney draw a plate of Pitha and a bowl of Curd?
m3: Historical Atiya Jame Mosque

Cats can explore the 17th-century mosque which is a blend of Islamic and Bengali architecture. The intricate woodcarvings, colored glasses, and calligraphic inscriptions are worth seeing. Be respectful and cover the paws while entering the Mosque.
Can Midjourney depict a cat sitting outside the Atiya Jame Mosque?
